messageBody:
On Wed, 11 Jun 2003 16:11:02 -0700 (PDT), "balakrishnan sengodan"
<bsengodan@...> said:
> Jason: Thanks for your reply. As you have mentioned in
> your reply, we need to write a getCount() mthod to get
> the value of the "counter". We do not want to do this.
> Without "GET" method, is there any way we can get the
> value of the "counter".
> Thanks
> Balakrishnan
> ================
> public void testIncrementBy() {
> > Counter counter = new Counter();
> > assertEquals("initial value", 0,
> > counter.getCount());
> >
> > counter.incrementBy(5);
> > assertEquals("incremented value", 5,
> > counter.getCount());
>

I don't see exactly why you would want this. Perhaps it's legacy code
which you can't change? In that case there are ways to get at private
internals. If that's the case, search this group's archives for "testing
private" and you should find your answer there.

However, if you are designing the system from scratch you should have the
flexibility to make it modular enough that you don't have to test without
some sort of getter method. If your coding standard is simply to not
pollute the system with getters/setters then there MUST be some object
somewhere that will respond to the change resulting from the call to the
void method. There must be a way to test it in that case. I would argue
though that the getter is probably not that bad of an idea -- it
represents access to a data object, an object that holds some data
representative of a particular state -- therefore, you must have a way to
get at that state/data.

Hope that helps,
=jason
